{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3217541,"name":"Smtopps","username":"Smtopps","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/smtopps/{size}/166758_2.png","created_at":"2023-07-07T00:02:52.313Z","cooked":"

I’m working on a presentation about simplicity that would be similar to the presentations by Adam Heard. Along with this I would like to compile a list of simple robots over the years. I’m also thinking about simple robots relative to their performance. I’m also not worried about the drive train as I am mostly focused on the mechanisms.

Here are my primary examples from this year:
9098: simple robot that only scores cubes but is fast and needs very little resources
695: good all around robot that can pick cones and cubes from the floor and score anywhere. It only uses an elevator and everybot style intake.
973: compact, no pneumatics, fast, doesn’t need to get the game pieces in a gap.

I’d like to nominate 88 and 971 to this list

Whoops, this isnt the super complicated bot thread

In actuality, 9101 from up here in NE had a great low cube scorer, they went all the way to worlds this year.
1922 and 1923 as well

Edit: 971, not 973

2910’s Deep Space robot (2019) is one of my favourites that year, and IMO was an extremely clean and simple design. Not to mention an absolute beast on the field.

David

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-07-07T00:52:08.739Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":596,"readers_count":595,"score":204.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":438720,"topic_slug":"looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years","display_username":"David Allred","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12651,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4451 CAD Mentor and Coach"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years/438720/4","custom_user_title":"4451 CAD Mentor and Coach","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3217552,"name":"Luin","username":"LuiTheFly","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/luithefly/{size}/175341_2.png","created_at":"2023-07-07T00:53:57.191Z","cooked":"

There is this presentation by Adam Heard called “Simple Robots That Win” that runs over a few good simple robots from over the years. The slides and videos are a bit hard to see because of the glare, but you can find the slide deck here.

Personally I think that 2910 is the greastest example of simple robots there is. Since 2018 they have built super simple robots that perform spectacularly at the highest levels of play.

Edit: IDK how I missed that you mentioned Adam’s presentation in your OP, oops. But I guess the links there now for anyone to quickly get to it.
Also sorry Brian, I didnt mean to reply to your post and I don’t know how to fix it.

Simple Robots that Win - YouTube","clicks":40}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19532,"username":"cad321","name":"Brian Wagg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":9}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30778,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Luin | 5985 Mentor | Ri3D Unqualified Quokkas"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years/438720/5","custom_user_title":"Luin | 5985 Mentor | Ri3D Unqualified Quokkas","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":9,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3217553,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-07-07T00:58:24.013Z","cooked":"

Careful equating “no pneumatics” with simple, a lot of times linear motion is way more difficult to package and do cleanly (let alone light weight) with motors.

To add to the list of simple and effective:

  • 148 in 2009
  • A whole host of 2011 machines that had simple extending tube arms
  • 4656 in 2013 (low goal frisbee dump, not sure if match video or images survive)
  • 2481 in 2014
  • 876 in 2016
  • 3310 in 2023

I may be a little biased but 5727 Omegabyte’s bot this year was incredibly simple, the arm was aluminum extrusions and the intake was fairly simple, and no motor for the wrist, because theres a v4bar

bcon:

I’d like to nominate 88 and 973 to this list

973 generally has some pretty sweet simple robots. They often make me kick myself for not thinking of the obvious solution that has limited excess complexity but is highly competitive.

This thread is great for 2023 robots

Achievable All-Stars General Forum
I see a lot of people trying to emulate what teams like 254, 1323, and 4414 do on their robots, and while those robots are awesome, they’re not quite what the average team should be trying to build. What are some of the most achievable robots out there this season that teams looking to up their game should try and emulate?

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-07-07T11:35:44.243Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":438,"readers_count":437,"score":102.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":438720,"topic_slug":"looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years","display_username":"Brendan Conover","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":26137,"username":"ndp","name":"Nicholas Dal Porto","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ndp/{size}/238692_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52398,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"washed alum|frcdesign.org"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years/438720/12","custom_user_title":"washed alum|frcdesign.org","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3217611,"name":"Brennan Macaig","username":"brennan-macaig","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brennan-macaig/{size}/205614_2.png","created_at":"2023-07-07T13:42:15.908Z","cooked":"

Here in New England again, 133 from every year. Their robots are always the simplest way to achieve the game tasks, with weeks of drive practice and great execution. This year their manipulator was a pinching claw (not touch it own it, no spinning wheels, only from double substation) and they were NE DCMP finalists. Every year I watch their robot and think “why didn’t we just do that…”

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-07-07T13:42:52.921Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":401,"readers_count":400,"score":145.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":438720,"topic_slug":"looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years","display_username":"Brennan Macaig","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27431,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FTAA/CSA, first alum, 6324 mentor [he/him]"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years/438720/13","custom_user_title":"FTAA/CSA, first alum, 6324 mentor [he/him]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3217621,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-07-07T15:25:32.971Z","cooked":"

Adding to the list again, I’m surprised 2056 hasn’t been mentioned yet.

They are by all definitions a world class team, who consistently make simple/elegant machines and then push said designs to their absolute limits.

There is the aspect that they tend to do all the given tasks each year, which definitely increases the complexity of their machine from what it maybe could be if it “specialized” more for a specific game task; But I’d still consider them a phenomenal example of how to design and implement a simple robot.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-07-07T15:25:32.971Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":383,"readers_count":382,"score":136.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":438720,"topic_slug":"looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years/438720/14","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3217622,"name":"","username":"Kevin_Leonard","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kevin_leonard/{size}/237299_2.png","created_at":"2023-07-07T15:44:25.501Z","cooked":"

The examples in this thread given as “simple” bother me a bit. I think of “simple” as something like one degree of freedom plus a spinning roller, or two degrees of freedom, but done in a way that simplifies the system’s controls (limited ranges of motion, one of the DOF is pneumatic, etc.).

Telescoping tubing mechanisms (greater than 1 stage, or any telescoping thing prior to the release of telescoping tubing COTS kits) are not particularly easy to build.

  • Cube shooters like 1561 and 1923 are excellent examples of simple top-tier robots this year.
  • Top tier everybot+ designs like 3176 and especially 1591 were excellent with limited degrees of freedom.

Slightly more complex:

  • 5414 had a single degree of freedom arm + rollers for cones and a separate cube shooting mechanism (which they did make pretttty complex)
  • 695 appears to be a 3 stage elevator, which is more complex to build than a single jointed arm, but they offset that by having no wrist or separate intake mechanism

Kevin_Leonard:

695 appears to be a 3 stage elevator, which is more complex to build than a single jointed arm, but they offset that by having no wrist or separate intake mechanism

With the availability of several COTS elevator kits now, I don’t fully agree with this, especially if everyone is using brushless motors (encoders for creating set points and PID control are way easier than in the past).

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-07-07T15:54:57.874Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":341,"readers_count":340,"score":68.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":438720,"topic_slug":"looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8002,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"177 & 429 | #TeamWCP| #TeamThrifty"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years/438720/16","custom_user_title":"177 & 429 | #TeamWCP| #TeamThrifty","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3217625,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-07-07T16:06:27.839Z","cooked":"

My recommendations (and im assuming some others here) were not based on being soley “simple”. They were based upon what OP asked:

Smtopps:

I’m also thinking about simple robots relative to their performance.

Based on this, I stand by the teams I’ve listed and their “simplicity”.

“Simple” can also be rather subjective given the vast differences in manufacturing capabilities between teams. For a team with only access to hand drills and hacksaws, teams like 2056 or 2910 would likey be far too complex. For teams with access to CNC/precision machining, I’d absolutely consider those teams/designs as simple.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-07-07T16:08:53.952Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":338,"readers_count":337,"score":67.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":438720,"topic_slug":"looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16805,"username":"Kevin_Leonard","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kevin_leonard/{size}/237299_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-examples-of-simple-robots-over-the-years/438720/17","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3217636,"name":"bobbysq","username":"bobbysq","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobbysq/{size}/195893_2.png","created_at":"2023-07-07T17:31:18.056Z","cooked":"

I submit 4646’s 2016 robot as a simple, but effective design:

The intake was a notable weak point, but two revisions were made, first one that added a plastic sheet to contain the ball:

Then a much better one inspired by 1756’s intake from that year:

image960×704 64.1 KB

While its on-field performance could have been better, I can’t really say I would have wanted the overall design to be different all these years later. Sometimes I think about what could have happened if we had a better camera mount, the radio wiring was more stable, or the auto was more consistent…
